qas.question: Who briefly seized St. John's in 1665?
In what year did the dutch attack St. John for a second time?
How many men defended the attack from the Dutch in 1673?
How many Dutch warships were fended of by Christopher Martin in 1673?
What admiral seized St. Johns in the 16th century?
Who defended St. Johns from a second dutch attack in the 16th century?
How many men were with Martin when he defeated the Dutch merchant ships?
When did the Dutch plan to expand St. Johns fortifications?

plausible_answers.text: French admiral Pierre Le Moyne d'Iberville

qas.question: Who reduced St. Johns to rubble in the 16th century?

context: The town's first significant defences were likely erected due to commercial interests, following the temporary seizure of St. John's by the <b5_0>Dutch admiral <a0_0>Michiel de Ruyter<b5_0/><a0_0/> in June 1665. The inhabitants were able to fend off a second Dutch attack in <a1_0>1673<a1_0/>, when this time it was defended by <b6_0>Christopher Martin<b6_0/>, an English merchant captain. Martin landed six cannons from his vessel, the Elias Andrews, and constructed an earthen breastwork and battery near chain Rock commanding the Narrows leading into the harbour. With only <a2_0><b7_0>twenty-three<b7_0/><a2_0/> men, the valiant Martin beat off an attack by <a4_0>three<a4_0/> Dutch warships. The English government planned to expand these fortifications (Fort William) in around <b8_0>1689<b8_0/>, but actual construction didn't begin until after the <b9_0>French admiral <a3_0>Pierre Le Moyne<a3_0/> d'Iberville<b9_0/> captured and destroyed the town in the Avalon Peninsula Campaign (1696). When 1500 English reinforcements arrived in late 1697 they found nothing but rubble where the town and fortifications had stood.
